2#define UVW_LOOP_INCLUDE_H

4
5#ifdef _WIN32
6#include <ciso646>
7#endif
8
9#include <functional>
10#include <memory>
11#include <utility>
12#include <type_traits>
13#include <chrono>
14#include <uv.h>
15#include "emitter.h"
16#include "util.h"
17
18
19namespace uvw {
20
21
22namespace details {
23
24
25enum class UVLoopOption: std::underlying_type_t<uv_loop_option> {
26 BLOCK_SIGNAL = UV_LOOP_BLOCK_SIGNAL
27};
28
29
30enum class UVRunMode: std::underlying_type_t<uv_run_mode> {
31 DEFAULT = UV_RUN_DEFAULT,
32 ONCE = UV_RUN_ONCE,
33 NOWAIT = UV_RUN_NOWAIT
34};
35
36
37}
38
39
40/**
41 * @brief Untyped handle class
42 *
43 * Handles' types are unknown from the point of view of the loop.<br/>
44 * Anyway, a loop maintains a list of all the associated handles and let the
45 * users walk them as untyped instances.<br/>
46 * This can help to end all the pending requests by closing the handles.
47 */
48struct BaseHandle {
49 virtual ~BaseHandle() = default;
50 /**
51 * @brief Gets the category of the handle.
52 *
53 * A base handle offers no functionality to promote it to the actual handle
54 * type. By means of this function, an opaque value that identifies the
55 * category of the handle is made available to the users.
56 *
57 * @return The actual category of the handle.
58 */
59 virtual HandleCategory category() const noexcept = 0;
60
61 /**
62 * @brief Gets the type of the handle.
63 *
64 * A base handle offers no functionality to promote it to the actual handle
65 * type. By means of this function, the type of the underlying handle as
66 * specified by HandleType is made available to the user.
67 *
68 * @return The actual type of the handle.
69 */
70 virtual HandleType type() const noexcept = 0;
71
72 /**
73 * @brief Checks if the handle is active.
74 *
75 * What _active_ means depends on the type of handle:
76 *
77 * * An AsyncHandle handle is always active and cannot be deactivated,
78 * except by closing it with uv_close().
79 * * A PipeHandle, TCPHandle, UDPHandle, etc. handle - basically any handle
80 * that deals with I/O - is active when it is doing something that involves
81 * I/O, like reading, writing, connecting, accepting new connections, etc.
82 * * A CheckHandle, IdleHandle, TimerHandle, etc. handle is active when it
83 * has been started with a call to `start()`.
84 *
85 * Rule of thumb: if a handle of type `FooHandle` has a `start()` member
86 * method, then it’s active from the moment that method is called. Likewise,
87 * `stop()` deactivates the handle again.
88 *
89 * @return True if the handle is active, false otherwise.
90 */
91 virtual bool active() const noexcept = 0;
92
93 /**
94 * @brief Checks if a handle is closing or closed.
95 *
96 * This function should only be used between the initialization of the
97 * handle and the arrival of the close callback.
98 *
99 * @return True if the handle is closing or closed, false otherwise.
100 */
101 virtual bool closing() const noexcept = 0;
102
103 /**
104 * @brief Reference the given handle.
105 *
106 * References are idempotent, that is, if a handle is already referenced
107 * calling this function again will have no effect.
108 */
109 virtual void reference() noexcept = 0;
110
111 /**
112 * @brief Unreference the given handle.
113 *
114 * References are idempotent, that is, if a handle is not referenced calling
115 * this function again will have no effect.
116 */
117 virtual void unreference() noexcept = 0;
118
119 /**
120 * @brief Checks if the given handle referenced.
121 * @return True if the handle referenced, false otherwise.
122 */
123 virtual bool referenced() const noexcept = 0;
124
125 /**
126 * @brief Request handle to be closed.
127 *
128 * This **must** be called on each handle before memory is released.<br/>
129 * In-progress requests are cancelled and this can result in an ErrorEvent
130 * emitted.
131 */
132 virtual void close() noexcept = 0;
133};
134
135
136/**
137 * @brief The Loop class.
138 *
139 * The event loop is the central part of `uvw`'s functionalities, as well as
140 * `libuv`'s ones.<br/>
141 * It takes care of polling for I/O and scheduling callbacks to be run based on
142 * different sources of events.
143 */
144class Loop final: public Emitter<Loop>, public std::enable_shared_from_this<Loop> {
145 using Deleter = void(*)(uv_loop_t *);
146
147 template<typename, typename>
148 friend class Resource;
149
150 Loop(std::unique_ptr<uv_loop_t, Deleter> ptr) noexcept;
151
152public:
153 using Time = std::chrono::duration<uint64_t, std::milli>;
154 using Configure = details::UVLoopOption;
155 using Mode = details::UVRunMode;
156
157 /**
158 * @brief Initializes a new Loop instance.
159 * @return A pointer to the newly created loop.
160 */
161 static std::shared_ptr<Loop> create();
162
163 /**
164 * @brief Initializes a new Loop instance from an existing resource.
165 *
166 * The lifetime of the resource must exceed that of the instance to which
167 * it's associated. Management of the memory associated with the resource is
168 * in charge of the user.
169 *
170 * @param loop A valid pointer to a correctly initialized resource.
171 * @return A pointer to the newly created loop.
172 */
173 static std::shared_ptr<Loop> create(uv_loop_t *loop);
174
175 /**
176 * @brief Gets the initialized default loop.
177 *
178 * It may return an empty pointer in case of failure.<br>
179 * This function is just a convenient way for having a global loop
180 * throughout an application, the default loop is in no way different than
181 * the ones initialized with `create()`.<br>
182 * As such, the default loop can be closed with `close()` so the resources
183 * associated with it are freed (even if it is not strictly necessary).
184 *
185 * @return The initialized default loop.
186 */
187 static std::shared_ptr<Loop> getDefault();
188
189 Loop(const Loop &) = delete;
190 Loop(Loop &&other) = delete;
191 Loop & operator=(const Loop &) = delete;
192 Loop & operator=(Loop &&other) = delete;
193
194 ~Loop() noexcept;
195
196 /**
197 * @brief Sets additional loop options.
198 *
199 * You should normally call this before the first call to uv_run() unless
200 * mentioned otherwise.<br/>
201 * Supported options:
202 *
203 * * `Loop::Configure::BLOCK_SIGNAL`: Block a signal when polling for new
204 * events. A second argument is required and it is the signal number.
205 *
206 * An ErrorEvent will be emitted in case of errors.
207 *
208 * See the official
209 * [documentation](http://docs.libuv.org/en/v1.x/loop.html#c.uv_loop_configure)
210 * for further details.
211 */
212 template<typename... Args>
213 void configure(Configure flag, Args&&... args) {
214 auto option = static_cast<std::underlying_type_t<Configure>>(flag);
215 auto err = uv_loop_configure(loop.get(), static_cast<uv_loop_option>(option), std::forward<Args>(args)...);
216 if(err) { publish(ErrorEvent{err}); }
217 }
218
219 /**
220 * @brief Creates resources of any type.
221 *
222 * This should be used as a default method to create resources.<br/>
223 * The arguments are the ones required for the specific resource.
224 *
225 * Use it as `loop->resource<uvw::TimerHandle>()`.
226 *
227 * @return A pointer to the newly created resource.
228 */
229 template<typename R, typename... Args>
230 std::shared_ptr<R> resource(Args&&... args) {
231 if constexpr(std::is_base_of_v<BaseHandle, R>) {
232 auto ptr = R::create(shared_from_this(), std::forward<Args>(args)...);
233 ptr = ptr->init() ? ptr : nullptr;
234 return ptr;
235 } else {
236 return R::create(shared_from_this(), std::forward<Args>(args)...);
237 }
238 }
239
240 /**
241 * @brief Releases all internal loop resources.
242 *
243 * Call this function only when the loop has finished executing and all open
244 * handles and requests have been closed, or the loop will emit an error.
245 *
246 * An ErrorEvent will be emitted in case of errors.
247 */
248 void close();
249
250 /**
251 * @brief Runs the event loop.
252 *
253 * Available modes are:
254 *
255 * * `Loop::Mode::DEFAULT`: Runs the event loop until there are no more
256 * active and referenced handles or requests.
257 * * `Loop::Mode::ONCE`: Poll for i/o once. Note that this function blocks
258 * if there are no pending callbacks.
259 * * `Loop::Mode::NOWAIT`: Poll for i/o once but don’t block if there are no
260 * pending callbacks.
261 *
262 * See the official
263 * [documentation](http://docs.libuv.org/en/v1.x/loop.html#c.uv_run)
264 * for further details.
265 *
266 * @return True when done, false in all other cases.
267 */
268 template<Mode mode = Mode::DEFAULT>
269 bool run() noexcept;
270
271 /**
272 * @brief Checks if there are active resources.
273 * @return True if there are active resources in the loop.
274 */
275 bool alive() const noexcept;
276
277 /**
278 * @brief Stops the event loop.
279 *
280 * It causes `run()` to end as soon as possible.<br/>
281 * This will happen not sooner than the next loop iteration.<br/>
282 * If this function was called before blocking for I/O, the loop won’t block
283 * for I/O on this iteration.
284 */
285 void stop() noexcept;
286
287 /**
288 * @brief Get backend file descriptor.
289 *
290 * Only kqueue, epoll and event ports are supported.<br/>
291 * This can be used in conjunction with `run<Loop::Mode::NOWAIT>()` to poll
292 * in one thread and run the event loop’s callbacks in another.
293 *
294 * @return The backend file descriptor.
295 */
296 int descriptor() const noexcept;
297
298 /**
299 * @brief Gets the poll timeout.
300 * @return A `std::pair` composed as it follows:
301 * * A boolean value that is true in case of valid timeout, false otherwise.
302 * * Milliseconds (`std::chrono::duration<uint64_t, std::milli>`).
303 */
304 std::pair<bool, Time> timeout() const noexcept;
305
306 /**
307 * @brief Returns the current timestamp in milliseconds.
308 *
309 * The timestamp is cached at the start of the event loop tick.<br/>
310 * The timestamp increases monotonically from some arbitrary point in
311 * time.<br/>
312 * Don’t make assumptions about the starting point, you will only get
313 * disappointed.
314 *
315 * @return The current timestamp in milliseconds (actual type is
316 * `std::chrono::duration<uint64_t, std::milli>`).
317 */
318 Time now() const noexcept;
319
320 /**
321 * @brief Updates the event loop’s concept of _now_.
322 *
323 * The current time is cached at the start of the event loop tick in order
324 * to reduce the number of time-related system calls.<br/>
325 * You won’t normally need to call this function unless you have callbacks
326 * that block the event loop for longer periods of time, where _longer_ is
327 * somewhat subjective but probably on the order of a millisecond or more.
328 */
329 void update() const noexcept;
330
331 /**
332 * @brief Walks the list of handles.
333 *
334 * The callback will be executed once for each handle that is still active.
335 *
336 * @param callback A function to be invoked once for each active handle.
337 */
338 void walk(std::function<void(BaseHandle &)> callback);
339
340 /**
341 * @brief Reinitialize any kernel state necessary in the child process after
342 * a fork(2) system call.
343 *
344 * Previously started watchers will continue to be started in the child
345 * process.
346 *
347 * It is necessary to explicitly call this function on every event loop
348 * created in the parent process that you plan to continue to use in the
349 * child, including the default loop (even if you don’t continue to use it
350 * in the parent). This function must be called before calling any API
351 * function using the loop in the child. Failure to do so will result in
352 * undefined behaviour, possibly including duplicate events delivered to
353 * both parent and child or aborting the child process.
354 *
355 * When possible, it is preferred to create a new loop in the child process
356 * instead of reusing a loop created in the parent. New loops created in the
357 * child process after the fork should not use this function.
358 *
359 * Note that this function is not implemented on Windows.<br/>
360 * Note also that this function is experimental in `libuv`. It may contain
361 * bugs, and is subject to change or removal. API and ABI stability is not
362 * guaranteed.
363 *
364 * An ErrorEvent will be emitted in case of errors.
365 *
366 * See the official
367 * [documentation](http://docs.libuv.org/en/v1.x/loop.html#c.uv_loop_fork)
368 * for further details.
369 */
370 void fork() noexcept;
371
372 /**
373 * @brief Gets user-defined data. `uvw` won't use this field in any case.
374 * @return User-defined data if any, an invalid pointer otherwise.
375 */
376 template<typename R = void>
377 std::shared_ptr<R> data() const {
378 return std::static_pointer_cast<R>(userData);
379 }
380
381 /**
382 * @brief Sets arbitrary data. `uvw` won't use this field in any case.
383 * @param uData User-defined arbitrary data.
384 */
385 void data(std::shared_ptr<void> uData);
386
387 /**
388 * @brief Gets the underlying raw data structure.
389 *
390 * This function should not be used, unless you know exactly what you are
391 * doing and what are the risks.<br/>
392 * Going raw is dangerous, mainly because the lifetime management of a loop,
393 * a handle or a request is in charge to the library itself and users should
394 * not work around it.
395 *
396 * @warning
397 * Use this function at your own risk, but do not expect any support in case
398 * of bugs.
399 *
400 * @return The underlying raw data structure.
401 */
402 const uv_loop_t * raw() const noexcept;
403
404 /**
405 * @brief Gets the underlying raw data structure.
406 *
407 * This function should not be used, unless you know exactly what you are
408 * doing and what are the risks.<br/>
409 * Going raw is dangerous, mainly because the lifetime management of a loop,
410 * a handle or a request is in charge to the library itself and users should
411 * not work around it.
412 *
413 * @warning
414 * Use this function at your own risk, but do not expect any support in case
415 * of bugs.
416 *
417 * @return The underlying raw data structure.
418 */
419 uv_loop_t * raw() noexcept;
420
421private:
422 std::unique_ptr<uv_loop_t, Deleter> loop;
423 std::shared_ptr<void> userData{nullptr};
424};
425
426
427// (extern) explicit instantiations
428
429extern template bool Loop::run<Loop::Mode::DEFAULT>() noexcept;
430extern template bool Loop::run<Loop::Mode::ONCE>() noexcept;
431extern template bool Loop::run<Loop::Mode::NOWAIT>() noexcept;
432
433
434}
435
436

438#include "loop.cpp"
439#endif
440
441#endif // UVW_LOOP_INCLUDE_H
